com.salesforce.omakase.ast.declaration

Class NumericalValue

  • java.lang.Object
    • com.salesforce.omakase.ast.AbstractSyntax
      • com.salesforce.omakase.ast.collection.AbstractGroupable<PropertyValue,PropertyValueMember>
        • com.salesforce.omakase.ast.declaration.AbstractTerm
          • com.salesforce.omakase.ast.declaration.NumericalValue
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    Groupable<PropertyValue,PropertyValueMember>, PropertyValueMember, Term, Syntax, Broadcastable, Writable

    public final class NumericalValue
extends AbstractTerm
    A numerical value (e.g., 1 or 1px or 3.5em).

    The unit is optional and is any keyword directly following the number value, such as px, em, or ms. The sign is also optional, and is only defined if explicitly included in the source. In other words, in "5px" the sign will not be NumericalValue.Sign.POSITIVE but an empty Optional.

    To dynamically create a NumericalValue use on of the constructor methods, for example: 

     NumericalValue number = NumericalValue.of(10, "px");
    See Also:
    NumericalValueParser

      • value

        public String value()
        Gets the numerical value as a string.

        Note that if the value is negative, it will not be shown here, see explicitSign(), or for mathematical operations see intValue() or doubleValue().

        For math operations, doubleValue() is available instead.

        Returns:
        The numerical value.

      • doubleValue

        public double doubleValue()
        Gets the numerical value as a double.

        Note that this may result in an exception if the current string value is too large for a double. This performs a calculation so cache the result if using more than once.

        Returns:
        The double value.

      • intValue

        public int intValue()
        Gets the numerical value as an integer. Usually you should use doubleValue() instead unless you are ok with discarding any present decimal value. This performs a calculation so cache the result if using more than once.
        Returns:
        The int value.

      • write

        public void write(StyleWriter writer,
                  StyleAppendable appendable)
           throws IOException
        Description copied from interface: Writable
        Outputs this Writable's string representation.

        Important notes for implementation:

        Do not use the StyleWriter in an attempt to write direct content (Strings, chars, etc...). Use the StyleAppendable.

        The StyleWriter should be used to make decisions based on writer settings (e.g., compressed vs. verbose output mode), as well as for writing inner or child Writables. Do not call the this method method directly on inner or child Writables! That would bypass any overrides that are set on the StyleWriter. Use StyleWriter.writeInner(Writable, StyleAppendable) instead.

        Parameters:
        writer - Writer to use for output settings and for writing inner Writables.
        appendable - Append direct content to this StyleAppendable.
        Throws:
        IOException - If an I/O error occurs.

      • of

        public static NumericalValue of(String value)
        Creates a new NumericalValue instance with the given raw value. Generally this should not be preferred unless using one of the other constructor methods would result in precision errors.

        Example: 

         NumericalValue.of("1000000000.0000000009")
        Parameters:
        value - The raw numerical value. Must not contain the sign or unit.
        Returns:
        The new NumericalValue instance.
